bhtAttempts.bht: The account of Mark 15:9 differs from Matthew and agrees with John, emphasizing the sharp contrast between Jesus and Barabbas. Pilate's mention of Jesus as The King of the Jews in his charge heightens this contrast and seeks to provoke the crowd to choose Barabbas over Jesus. It is evident that Pilate, aware of Jesus' innocence, attempts to appease the crowd by repeating the title that he knows will enrage them. However, in doing so, he sacrifices justice for the sake of popular clamor.

The account of this event differs from Matthew and agrees with John, as it highlights the contrast between Jesus and Barabbas. Pilate's charge of Jesus as The King of the Jews sharpens this contrast and aims to influence the crowd's decision. By repeating this title, Pilate knowingly provokes the crowd, sacrificing justice for the sake of their clamor.

The account of this event differs from Matthew and aligns with John in emphasizing the contrast between Jesus and Barabbas. Pilate's charge of Jesus as The King of the Jews sharpens this contrast and seeks to influence the crowd's decision. Aware of Jesus' innocence, Pilate repeats this title, sacrificing justice to appease the crowd and their clamor.
